summary: This is a court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF). The evidence includes Maxwell's deposition transcripts from a prior civil defamation case. Maxwell argued the subpoena violated her Fifth and Fourth Amendment rights and due process, but the court found no constitutional violation and denied both suppression and an evidentiary hearing.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who moved to suppress evidence (her deposition transcripts) obtained from her prior civil litigation via a grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge who authored this opinion and order denying Maxwell's motion to suppress evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the individual Maxwell was accused alongside of sexually abusing the plaintiff in the prior civil defamation case, and as the target of the government's investigation.

persons.name: Judge McMahon
persons.context: Then-Chief Judge who heard the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order in the civil case and granted it, allowing BSF to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Magistrate Judge Netburn
persons.context: Denied a similar government application in another case, applying the same legal standard but reaching a different conclusion on the 'extraordinary circumstances' factor.

connections.description: Maxwell was accused in the civil case of defaming the plaintiff by accusing her of lying about Maxwell and Epstein sexually abusing her. The government's notes from a 2016 meeting identified Maxwell as Epstein's 'head recruiter' of underage girls.

Judge McMahon presided over the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order from Maxwell's civil case, which allowed the government to obtain Maxwell's deposition transcripts via subpoena.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge in Maxwell's criminal case, ruling on her motion to suppress evidence obtained from the civil litigation.

events.title: Civil Defamation Lawsuit Filed
events.description: An individual (plaintiff) sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, alleging Maxwell accused her of lying about being sexually abused by Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Meeting Between BSF Attorneys and AUSA
events.description: Three attorneys from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF), representing the plaintiff in the civil case, met with an Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) to provide information on possible criminal conduct, focusing on Epstein and identifying Maxwell as his 'head recruiter'.

events.title: Formal Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York formally opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein following Miami Herald articles about his conduct and prior plea deal.

events.title: First Ex Parte Hearing on Protective Order
events.description: Judge McMahon held the first ex parte hearing on the government's application to modify the protective order from Maxwell's civil case, citing the Martindell precedent.

events.title: Second Ex Parte Hearing and Order
events.description: Judge McMahon held a second ex parte hearing, asked about prior contacts between the U.S. Attorney's Office and BSF, and later issued a sealed order and opinion granting the government's application to modify the protective order.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Suppress
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued this opinion and order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence obtained via the grand jury subpoena to BSF and for an evidentiary hearing.

keyFacts: The government obtained Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition transcripts from a prior civil defamation case via a grand jury subpoena served on the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF), after a court modified the case's protective order.

Maxwell argued the subpoena violated her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, her Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable search/seizure, and her due process rights, but the court rejected all arguments.

The court found Maxwell had no reasonable expectation of privacy in documents produced in civil litigation, as protective orders are 'porous and ephemeral' and do not guarantee against use in subsequent criminal proceedings.

Maxwell claimed the government misled Judge McMahon by not disclosing a 2016 meeting between BSF attorneys and an AUSA, but the court found no substantial showing of deliberate/reckless misrepresentation or that the omission was necessary to the judge's decision.
The deposition transcripts Maxwell sought to suppress are the basis for perjury charges (counts five and six of the SI superseding indictment) against her in the criminal case.
